title: Stocks Jump as Producer Prices Rise Less Than Expected; Chinese stocks rallied, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng rising 4.1%
text:
Investors have fixated on signals about the path of inflation as they try to gauge when the Federal Reserve will moderate its aggressive campaign of interest-rate increases. The central bank's swift lifting of rates as it seeks to tame price increases has helped drive the S&P 500 down 16% in 2022.

Data Tuesday showed that increases in U.S. supplier prices slowed in October. The producer-price index rose 8% on a 12-month basis, down from a revised increase of 8.4% in September and much lower than the 11.7% increase in March.

Stocks gained as investors latched onto the additional sign that inflation could be turning a corner. Last week, the S&P 500 notched its largest two-day percentage gain since 2020 after consumer-price data showed that inflationeased in October to its slowest pace since January.

Fed Vice Chair Lael Brainard said Monday that it likely will be appropriate soon to shift to a slower pace of interest-rate increases.

"Everybody is clamoring for that to happen, no matter which asset class you're looking at," said Mike Mullaney, director of global markets research at Boston Partners. "I think a pause is more imminent than it has been recently."

The producer-price figures added fuel to a rally that was already under way in U.S. stock futures Tuesday morning.

A meeting Monday between President Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping—the first in person between the two leaders since Mr. Biden took office—inspired hopes of an improvement in the strained relationship between the two countries.

Asia stocks rallied, pushed higher by China's new plan to ease pressure on its property market and its relaxing of Covid-19 pandemic controls. Hong Kong's Hang Seng jumped 4.1%. The index is now back in a bull market, measured as a rise of 20% or more from a recent low. In mainland China, the Shanghai Composite gained 1.6%.

"There is positive news streaming in from China, which is key to the global market and global economic outlook," said Seema Shah, chief global strategist at Principal Asset Management. "I think this is what is driving [the rally in stocks], that maybe 2023 can be a better year than 2022."

In Europe, the pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 added 0.4%.

Among individual stocks, Walmart shares jumped 7.5% after the retailer reported revenue that topped analyst expectations and raised its fiscal-year guidance.

U.S.-listed shares of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing rose 12% after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway reported a stake in the chipmaker.

Investors are continuing to watch for contagion from cryptocurrency markets, which have been hammered in the last week as the fallout continues from the collapse of crypto exchange FTX. On Tuesday, cryptocurrency prices were stable, with bitcoin rising 3.4% from its 5 p.m. ET price to about $16,957.

In the government bond market, the yield on the benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury note declined to 3.831%, from 3.865% Monday. Yields fall as bond prices rise.

Oil prices rose, with Brent crude adding 1% to $94.08 a barrel.
